EnglishExample.exItem: English examples of main clause Yes/No questions are:
Are you going to the store?
Will Sue buy the present for her mother?
Could the boy have hit the ball?

form.prompt: Key similar examples of main clause Yes/No questions in your language here:

radioGroup.prompt: For main clause Yes/No questions, does your language have one or more Yes/No question marker particles, words or complementizers?

radioGroup.radio: No, it is a clitic which attaches to another word

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the Yes/No question marker occur with respect to the rest of the question?
radioGroup.radio: Either side, but not both sides at the same time
Either side, or on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the Yes/No question markers appear on either side of the question?
radioGroup.radio: No, there are separate sets for each side
No, but an auxiliary is fronted, like in English

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the auxiliary occur with respect to the rest of the question?

radioGroup.radio: No, there is no marker or word order change in main clause Yes/No questions, just a difference in intonation or tone or other non-syntactic marking

form.instruction: You need to write a CC table pre-pass to separate the clitic so that it stands alone and also make a root entry for this clitic in your lexicon. Give the entry the category C, or add the feature C to the feature line to change the category for the syntax. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, no additional feature is needed.

In the lexicon, if this word does not already have the category C, add the feature C to the feature line to change the category for the syntax. If a different marker is used in embedded questions, add the feature +root to this entry. If this same marker is used in embedded questions, no additional feature is needed.

In the lexicon, mark those markers which can only occur initially with the feature CP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature CP-final. Do not enter either feature on any markers which can occur on either side.
